newsitem.title: MALTA: Palestinians want quicker final status talks -Israel.
newsitem.headline: Palestinians want quicker final status talks -Israel.

text.p: Israel said on Wednesday the Palestinian Authority wanted to speed up talks on the final status of the Palestinian territories.

Foreign Minister David Levy told reporters after meetings with Palestinian President Yasser Arafat and Planning Minister Nabil Shaath: "We are glad to see that they have expressed their will to accelerate the work on the final status.
"They have a tendency to accept this and I am certain that this is a constructive proposal on our part," he added.

Israel proposed last month that Israeli and Palestinian negotiators aim to complete within six months the talks on "final status" issues -- mainly Jerusalem, Israel's borders, refugees and the status of the Palestinian territories.
The Palestinians reacted with suspicion because Israel coupled this with a proposal to skip the next three stages of Israeli redeployment from parts of the occupied territories.
Levy did not say he was reviving the same proposal in its entirety and Palestinians were not available to comment.
The Israeli minister described the atmosphere at his meetings with the Palestinians as good and said they showed both sides wanted to put peace talks back on track.
"The wish to return to the right path exists. The negotiating table is the place where the two sides will be able to discuss their problems," he added.
For the second time in two days he proposed Israel and the Palestinians draft a code of conduct but he gave few details of what Israel envisaged.
"(We should) create a sort of code of conduct so that both sides will abide by their obligations and there is a will to continue and work towards this goal," he said.
The European Union has also proposed a code of conduct but theirs would bind Israel to stop building settlements or changing the demographic status in disputed areas.
Levy defended Israel's decision to start work on a settlement on a hillside in disputed East Jerusalem -- the immediate cause of the lastest crisis in peace talks.

"We are trying as far as possible to explain that work on (the settlement on) Jabal Abu Ghneim does not violate the agreement signed," he said. He was speaking in Hebrew, with translation into either English or Arabic.
French Foreign Ministry spokesman Yves Doutriaux told reporters that in talks with Arafat Levy said Israel was ready to build thousands of homes for non-Jews.
French Foreign Minister Herve de Charette, Egyptian Foreign Minister Amr Moussa and European special envoy Miguel Angel Moratinos were present at the meeting.
